description: Noise and congestion at Fenway park.  Spartan race this weekend.  Noise from Fenway speakers on Sat started at 7:30AM.  The activity of private or other concert events has dramatically increased the last couple years.  It's getting out of hand. I moved here ok w living next to a baseball stadium and late spring mid fall games.  Now it's multiple concerts, races, hockey, x games and private corporate events all year long.   It needs to be scaled back some.  It's adding to an already packed neighborhood, which is only getting denser.  Adding a huge noise and light pollution burden and at extended hours, year round.  This was and is a neighbor first and foremost. The park and neighborhood coexisted well for ages.  Now it seems like Fenway owners pimp the park out for anything and everything regardless of how the surrounding area is affected.  This needs to be looked at.  Change does not have to be a cacophony of noise thrusted on the people who live here. Let's do this correctly!!

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. The Boston Parks and Recreation Department apologizes for any confusion regarding the trees and the current capital improvement project. The project at Medal of Honor Park includes planting over fifty new trees which will bring diversity to vegetation of the park making a significant generational investment to the long term success of the park's tree canopy. The trees to be planted comprise a varied population of species that are suitable for Medal of Honor Park in terms of scale and environmental benefit resulting in more shaded park locations, bird habitat and diminished wind impact. New plantings will be located where the twelve trees were removed within the past week and additional trees will be planted along the park perimeter, pathways and the play area as discussed at the fourth Community Meeting held on March 23, 2016. Species will include red maples (14), horse chestnuts (3), honey locusts (3), london plane trees (4), red and swamp white oaks (16), lindens (3), disease resistant American Elms (4) along with ornamental tree species of redbuds (4) and magnolias (4) known for their seasonal display. . All but one tree that was removed were deemed in poor health and/or showing signs of decline posing a safety risk especially during high wind storm events. The one tree (in fair condition) was removed to improve access within the new playground limits. As part of the design process, evaluation of the park trees were provided by the City's Tree Division including the City Tree Warden and additional staff of trained Certified Arborists. Based on the provided evaluation and recommendations made on March 11, 2016, tree removals were identified and the breadth and location of specific removals were discussed at the fourth community meeting. Additional recommendations by the City's Tree Division included pre-treating for environmental stress brought about by construction, the Sugar Maples through the use of soil amendments. This work was donated and completed as part of a day of service by a certified arborist on Arbor Day 2016. . The Parks and Recreation Department has a commitment to the improvement and long term health the City's tree canopy. The new trees should provide a healthier, more resilient canopy which will promote an ecologically diverse green space within South Boston. If you have any questions, please contact Project Manageer Michele Folts at 617-961-3025. Thank you.

status_notes: Case Noted. There is a valid permit issued for the area around 79 West Concord Street. Moving Permits are not always issued at the exact street address of the resident that is moving. Different addresses could be due to convenience to the movers, or a conflict with another permit issued in the area. It is not illegal to attached a temporary sign to a tree, especially when no damage is done to the tree. The photo clearly shows that the sign is attached to the tree with plastic wrap which should be removed after the move. Trees are often used to reduce the amount of curb space affected by the permit, if trees were not used then even more space would be required to be posted with No Stopping signs, eliminating valuable parking spaces for area residents. However, Permit Puller, the company that obtained the permit, will be notified and asked to verify the location and will be reminded that the signs should be removed after the move.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for voicing your concerns about bicycling in the city. In a dense city with constrained right-of-way, we see bicycling as a transportation option that relieves pressure on our travel lanes and on the T. Many people choose to bike to their destinations, and we are working to provide them safe places to do so. We do understand the frustration that many people, regardless of how they are traveling, are not following the rules of the road. We partner with BPD to do proactive education, and have a robust program to help bicyclists travel safely, responsibly, and in accordance with the law.

description:
Last night my car was towed due to an emergency gas leak. I was three hours late to work trying to get my car back this morning, was told at the police station that I wouldn't have to pay for it because I was parked legally, but when I got to the tow lot, I was told I needed to pay $129. I called the police station and they said I did have to pay and need to go through the gas company for a refund. 

In total, this cost me three hours and $145 after transportation fees and an ATM fee because not only did nobody tell me I had to pay for it, Roberts Towing only takes cash. I don't understand why the police did not try to look up the registration by plate and call me to move my car. This would have saved me significant time, money and headache. If I'm lucky, I'll get the towing fee reimbursed but I'm out of luck for the rest of it. 

As a new resident to the city and state, I've experienced so many difficulties with basic processes that could so easily be improved.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern about perceived speeding to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our ?safety issues? map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. To get updates in your inbox, please join the mailing list at visionzeroboston.org/contact.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stops signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our “safety issues” map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid was repairing 25 feet of the gas main on Wabon St. They are required to post " No Parking Signs" 48 hours in advance of the work. National Grid usually posts the street in advance of the work, obviously in this case they did not. In addition I spoke to National Grid on why they worked past the permitted hours. In the first instance the supervisor sent the driver to the yard to get steel plates to secure the hole and the driver went to the wrong yard causing the crew to work late. Yesterday because of the heavy rain they needed to stay late to make sure the sidewalls of the hole was secure being back filling and paving. The work is now complete. The PWD told National Grid they must post ALL locations 48 hours in advance with no exceptions. They apologized and acknowledge that this should not have happened. That stated they do have a posting procedures in place and they have already spoken to the personnel involved to remind them of the mandatory requirement. The supervisor Terry Cleary will gladly take your call if you want to personally speak to a representative of National Grid. Note: Since there are 3 cases related this issue all of the responses will be the same. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

description:
Over a year ago, I requested speed humps on Virginia and Monadnock Streets. As I sit here, mopeds are flying up and down the one way roads - often in the wrong direction. This has been a daily occurrence all summer and into the fall. Since posting about this issue in May 2015, I have seen two efforts to solve the problem: 
1. On one afternoon, I saw a cop patrolling the intersection to ticket those who did not stop at the stop sign. Only ONCE in a year and a half have I seen someone enforcing the stop signs. As a stay-at-home mom, we are outside nearly every day, rain or snow or shine, so it is unlikely that  it has been patrolled more often and I just missed it.
2. A sign was hung that reads "Drive Slow" and has a picture of a running child. That's a nice gesture. However, the signs have been entirely ineffective considering the excessive speeding that still occurs at this intersection.

I ask you respectfully to please again consider my request for speed humps which will actually slow the traffic and lead to a safer road for my children and my neighbors' children. Please let me know the procedure on how to obtain these. Do I need a signed petition by neighbors? If so, I know this can happen.

Thank you.
Sincerely,
a concerned mother and neighbor 
The user entered the address: 68 Monadnock St, Boston, Massachusetts to see more details visit: http://seeclickfix.com/issues/3017136
